t: Proverbs 6
Parental Counsel
My*pn son, if you have become surety for your neighbor, Have*ln given a pledge for a stranger,
If*iln you have been snared with the words of your mouth, Have*ln been caught with the words of your mouth,
Do*ln this then, my son, and deliver yourself; Since*ln you have come into the hand of your neighbor, Go,*ln humble yourself, and importune your neighbor.
Give*ln no sleep to your eyes, Nor*ln slumber to your eyelids;
Deliver*ln yourself like a gazelle from the*i hunter’s*i hand And*ln like a bird from the hand of the fowler.
Go*ln to the ant, O sluggard, Observe*ln her ways and be wise,
Which,*ln having no chief, Officer*ln or ruler,
Prepares*ln her food in the summer And*iln gathers her provision in the harvest.
How*ln long will you lie down, O sluggard? When*ln will you arise from your sleep?
“A*ln little sleep, a little slumber, A*ln little folding of the hands to rest”—
Your*ln poverty will come in like a vagabond And*ln your need like an armed man.
A*ln worthless person, a wicked man, Is*ln the one who walks with a perverse mouth,
Who*ln winks with his eyes, who signals with his feet, Who*ln points with his fingers;
Who*ln with*i perversity in his heart continually devises evil, Who*ln spreads strife.
Therefore*ln his calamity will come suddenly; Instantly*ln he will be broken and there will be no healing.
There*ln are six things which the Lord*s hates, Yes,*ln seven which are an abomination to Him:
Haughty*ln eyes, a lying tongue, And*ln hands that shed innocent blood,
A*ln heart that devises wicked plans, Feet*ln that run rapidly to evil,
A*ln false witness who*i utters lies, And*ln one who spreads strife among brothers.
My*ln son, observe the commandment of your father And*ln do not forsake the teaching of your mother;
Bind*ln them continually on your heart; Tie*ln them around your neck.
When*ln you walk about, they will guide you; When*ln you sleep, they will watch over you; And*ln when you awake, they will talk to you.
For*ln the commandment is a lamp and the teaching is light; And*ln reproofs for discipline are the way of life
To*ln keep you from the evil woman, From*ln the smooth tongue of the adulteress.
Do*ln not desire her beauty in your heart, Nor*ln let her capture you with her eyelids.
For*ln on account of a harlot one*i is*i reduced*i to a loaf of bread, And*ln an adulteress hunts for the precious life.
Can*ln a man take fire in his bosom And*ln his clothes not be burned?
Or*ln can a man walk on hot coals And*ln his feet not be scorched?
So*ln is the one who goes in to his neighbor’s wife; Whoever*ln touches her will not go unpunished.
Men*ln do not despise a thief if he steals To*ln satisfy himself when he is hungry;
But*ln when he is found, he must repay sevenfold; He*ln must give all the substance of his house.
The*ln one who commits adultery with a woman is lacking sense; He*ln who would destroy himself does it.
Wounds*ln and disgrace he will find, And*ln his reproach will not be blotted out.
For*ln jealousy enrages a man, And*ln he will not spare in the day of vengeance.
He*ln will not accept any ransom, Nor*ln will he be satisfied though you give many gifts.
